Half of all courts in England and Wales were closed between 2010 and 2019. Today there are 27,000 fewer Crown Court sitting days than in 2016.

Victims are being let down by these failures and the record-breaking backlog of more than 56,000 cases.

New data shows that 18 per cent of cases had been outstanding for a year or more in the three months to December last year – up from 6% in the previous year.

The drop in convictions has come despite rising crime levels – with police dealing with a record 4,900 violent crimes per day.

Increasingly, this government is letting criminals off the hook.

Today Labour is calling for emergency action as analysis reveals the total number of convictions has fallen to a 10-year low.

It plummeted by more than a half for robbery, by 55% for theft, by 78% for criminal damage and arson and by 65% for fraud over the past decade.

There is an inevitable risk that once jury trials are suspended for certain crimes, they will never come back.

The Government should not drop the high standards of jury trials in the face of a challenge, but instead look at creative measures and reforms to meet it.

Replacing juries with a judge and two magistrates would reduce the diversity of those making life changing decisions about guilt.

As the #BlackLivesMatter movement makes its voice heard, it would be wrong to ignore the reality of unconscious bias in our justice system.

The crown court backlog stood at 37,000 cases before the crisis, and the Government did not consider restricting on jury trials. 

The backlog is now around 41,000 and the prospect is being raised. 

Why is this change proportionate now?

The right of an individual to “the lawful judgment of his equals” was enshrined in the Magna Carta of 1215.

Jury trials form part of the bedrock of our democracy.

It would be a historic mistake to limit them now.

My piece for @Telegraph 👇🏿

The crisis is not going to be over in a few weeks. The changes we make to our justice system today will shape it for decades to come.

https://t.co/3w1Yb9fjtH
Labour will do all it can, as the opposition, to help defeat the virus. But we will also press to ensure the justice system is never so vulnerable again.
Finally, we need a properly funded probation system, run by the state. Labour supports entirely reversing Chris Grayling’s shambolic reforms.

Sixth, the Lammy Review showed that disproportionality runs through the criminal justice system. 

As we reform the way we do justice, the principles of fairness, anti-discrimination and equality must be at the forefront of our plan.

Fifth, we had an overcrowded and crumbling prison system before the crisis – a legacy of underinvestment – but Covid-19 makes its problems even more acute.

Proper PPE for staff, mass testing and contact tracing is the only way out of a crisis in our prisons.

Fourth, there must be open justice during and after the crisis. With some exceptions, including certain family, criminal and youth cases, courts must be observable online. 

There can be no going back after the crisis. The online streaming of cases is a reform we should keep.

67% of criminal chambers, and 55% of all chambers, believe they could fold in three to six months without further support. Solicitors face challenges that are just as stark.

The Treasury and the justice department need to act urgently to ensure the legal profession survives.

Second, the system should do justice remotely where possible, but recognise some hearings or parts of them should be done face to face. 

Big courtrooms and other public buildings, currently empty, can be used for proper social distancing.

First, the Legal Aid, Sentencing and Punishment of Offenders Act 2012 (LASPO) decimated legal advice and representation for those who cannot afford it. The publicly funded profession has been brought to its knees. 

LASPO has to go. We should all commit to that now.

(THREAD) My op-ed with @LordCFalconer: It is those who need the protection of the law – usually those with the least – who are suffering the most.
